revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-21 16:16:14.000000000', 'message': 'Add notifications for deleting app creds by user

Without this patch, when an individual application credential is deleted
it emits a notification, but when all are deleted for a user there is no
notification (although this is only triggered when a user is deleted or
disabled or has a change in role assignments, all of which generate
their own notifications). This patch ensures audit notifications are
generated for every application credential that gets deleted.

Change-Id: I7c820931585802c7afa53727623ac05adee56248
'}]
commit_message:
Add notifications for deleting app creds by user

Without this patch, when an individual application credential is deleted
it emits a notification, but when all are deleted for a user there is no
notification (although this is only triggered when a user is deleted or
disabled or has a change in role assignments, all of which generate
their own notifications). This patch ensures audit notifications are
generated for every application credential that gets deleted.

Change-Id: I7c820931585802c7afa53727623ac05adee56248

commit_message:
Use immutable roles in tests

Without this patch, bootstrap emits deprecation warnings in the tests
about opting into immutable roles. This change follows the warnings'
advice so that the warnings no longer clutter up the log output.

Change-Id: I72acef2409acc5efad84390cd7f63683a9842a5a

commit_message:
Clean up UserGroups target enforcement callback

There is already a module-level target enforcement callback defined that
does the same thing, so we don't need to keep a static method defined in
the UserGroupsResource class.

Change-Id: I6db45aab764a1e56c6cdca56b26b86346d7500f8

messages: [{'account_id': 21798, 'date': '2019-09-23 12:02:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-09-24 16:23:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-09-24 16:23:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-09-24 16:24:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-23 12:02:37.000000000', 'message': 'Run FWaaS and SFC jobs on all file changes

When moving these tests to neutron-tempest-plugin, the jobs were
configured to run only on relevant files changes. Drop this restriction
so we check that any change to the repo will not break a stadium test.

This is in line with current configuration for bgpvpn and proposed one
for dynamic-routing

Change-Id: I81dc79150f2a7e2b099acad2e9a021d360dff799
'}]
commit_message:
Run FWaaS and SFC jobs on all file changes

When moving these tests to neutron-tempest-plugin, the jobs were
configured to run only on relevant files changes. Drop this restriction
so we check that any change to the repo will not break a stadium test.

This is in line with current configuration for bgpvpn and proposed one
for dynamic-routing

Change-Id: I81dc79150f2a7e2b099acad2e9a021d360dff799

commit_message:
Add application_credential as a CADF type

This change adds 'application_credential' as a
'data/security/credential' CADF type, so that upon creating the CADF
payload the target URI is set to a valid type and not to 'unknown'.

Change-Id: I201ce5983409d99cbcaf0f0081be857b3194fa79

Dan should be the +A here'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-09-24 13:41:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I mentioned this in IRC yesterday, but technically we could still run into problems if the computes are upgraded but still have a pinned config but I'm not sure how much we want to bend over backward for that at this point in Train. Meaning the pin could be lifted from conductor and restarted so we get passed the check here, and the computes are restarted after being upgraded to Train but until the control plane is restarted the deployment doesn't do a full removal of the pin on the computes and restart those, so we could hit a window where conductor allows the request, it gets to the dest compute and then when the dest casts to resize_instance on the source, it strips out the RequestSpec so that the source resize_instance method doesn't pass the RequestSpec to finish_resize on the dest and we still fail with the same thing. Would heal_allocations fix that for us?"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-09-24 13:45:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

(1 comment)

I was going to say maybe we just drop the service version check since service version depends on RPC version. However, if they have upgrade_levels unset or set to train, then we'd still try to send it off, even though we know there is something old in the deployment. I wonder if that's something we should strictly adhere to RPC-wise (i.e. drop the service version check and let them push aggressively) or help avoid them shooting themselves in the foot...

Anyway, probably better to get this into the queue sooner."}]

commit_message:
Reject migration with QoS port from conductor if RPC pinned

The MigrationTask in the conductor already checks the service version as
old computes cannot support migration with QoS port. However it is still
possible that every compute is new but the compute RPC API is pinned to
< 5.2. In this case the migration still cannot be supported.

This patch adds an extra RPC version check to the conductor.

Change-Id: Ib4e0b9ab050a59ab5a290e6eecea01b87c3bd4c6
Closes-Bug: #1844993

commit_message:
Fixing 404 URLs for Rocky

It would be preferable to backport
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/675667/ but the difficulty (merge
conflicts) in backporting it was considered too high for a small
change due to the dramatic difference in the doc structure from
rocky to latest (Train). Instead, it is proposed to merge
these nit link changes into stable only.

This patch was proposed directly to Rocky in conjunction
with these two backports:
1. https://review.opendev.org/676955
2. https://review.opendev.org/683945

Change-Id: I17ae42d5e14fa09f44f430ffa01c01c33a96f57e

The fourth release name criterion arguably implies that generic names of

Change-Id: I158a32b76aee559c194a4bcafa1482e0426e87f3
'}, {'created': '2019-08-21 20:42:20.000000000', 'message': 'Clarify proscription of generic release names

The fourth release name criterion arguably implies that generic names of
types of geographic features are not eligible, but is ambiguous and has
been the source of confusion. Reduce this by stating it explicitly.

Arguably this rule would have required an exception to be granted for
Pike, and thus could be considered a change in policy (though
interpretations on this seem to differ based on whether you are from
Boston or not).

Change-Id: I158a32b76aee559c194a4bcafa1482e0426e87f3
'}]
commit_message:
Clarify proscription of generic release names

The fourth release name criterion arguably implies that generic names of
types of geographic features are not eligible, but is ambiguous and has
been the source of confusion. Reduce this by stating it explicitly.

Arguably this rule would have required an exception to be granted for
Pike, and thus could be considered a change in policy (though
interpretations on this seem to differ based on whether you are from
Boston or not).

Change-Id: I158a32b76aee559c194a4bcafa1482e0426e87f3

commit_message:
octavia-lib: Drop singlespec

vmware-nsx and octavia itself are the only users of
octavia-lib (beside modules that we don't have packaged yet). Both are
python3 now so switching octavia-lib to python3 only is the next
logical step.

Change-Id: I6c0d5ecca93ae3c0c8bde26593e32d760b53c620

While this is a good addition, it explains only one of the *seven* names which was removed from the poll this time.'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 16:30:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Let me clarify that a bit.  While I think this is a good addition if we stick with our current process, in practice I think this is ultimately harmful.  Rather than reducing contention, it will increase it, and will force us to have discussions about things which are offensive to members of our very large community.  This is why I propose that we scrap the process entirely in favor of something that is far less likely to generate controversy or distraction.  Let's pick a new process which won't risk alienating people."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-08-21 16:38:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

> will force us to have discussions about things which are offensive to members of our very large community.

It doesn't force us to have the discussion in public, unlike what happens if those things win the poll (see: M release).

> Let's pick a new process which won't risk alienating people.

That's a fine discussion to have also, but I don't think it should block us from making sure our current documentation accurately reflects our de facto practice and the knowledge we've won from past experience."}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-08-21 16:57:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Zane Bitter wrote:

> > will force us to have discussions about things which are offensive to members of our very large community.
>
> It doesn't force us to have the discussion in public, unlike what
> happens if those things win the poll (see: M release).

Are you suggesting that people who find names inconsiderate should contact the coordinator privately, and the coordinator should provide no public explanation for why they were removed?  Should they automatically remove words, or use their own judgement if someone says "the word 'Train' is offensive"?

If so, that is all worth including in the document.

I still think it's a bad idea and will result in more contention rather than less.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-08-21 17:19:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I agree that we should remove abusive words from the poll options even before having the poll. But I also agree that it increases the subjectivity of the exercise.

This accurately describes the process we currently follow, so I'm +2 on merging this. That said, I think it reinforces the fact that the process is broken and needs to be reformed, ideally in favor of a deterministic process that removes subjectivity and sidesteps cultural issues."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-08-25 06:57:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

[{'created': '2019-08-21 15:53:02.000000000', 'message': "Align release naming process with practice

The actual conduct of the release naming process has diverged from that
which is documented. Bring them back into alignment by giving the naming
co-ordinator and the TC an explicit role in removing names that aren't
in line with the Code of Conduct's injunction to be considerate of our
global audience, prior to their inclusion in the poll.

Change-Id: I4a4b17bbbe2e3168c70b67594639946895ff4d1f
"}, {'created': '2019-08-21 20:40:30.000000000', 'message': "Align release naming process with practice

The actual conduct of the release naming process has diverged from that
which is documented. Bring them back into alignment by giving the naming
co-ordinator and the TC an explicit role in removing names that aren't
in line with the Code of Conduct's injunction to be considerate of our
global audience, prior to their inclusion in the poll.

Change-Id: I4a4b17bbbe2e3168c70b67594639946895ff4d1f
"}]
commit_message:
Align release naming process with practice

The actual conduct of the release naming process has diverged from that
which is documented. Bring them back into alignment by giving the naming
co-ordinator and the TC an explicit role in removing names that aren't
in line with the Code of Conduct's injunction to be considerate of our
global audience, prior to their inclusion in the poll.

Change-Id: I4a4b17bbbe2e3168c70b67594639946895ff4d1f

commit_message:
add the required and optional packages for watcher

There are number of client packages that are required by watcher in
order to function correctly. See

https://opendev.org/openstack/watcher/src/branch/master/watcher/common/clients.py

So add those as requires. Also, ceilometerclient is optional so we add
it as recommends instead.

Change-Id: Icd36642ba4509ac655aaa65c059dd61d763f7b9c
(cherry picked from commit 91947caf73a964929f03a1a916dcd7644d990aa1)
(cherry picked from commit 60766cca15ff9c08b2b8f8848077f35c13f3e46c)

commit_message:
[prometheus] Added support for extra options

This change introduces the way to pass extra options to prometheus.

Currently, prometheus runs with nearly default options, and when clouds
start getting bigger, you need to pass extra parameters to prometheus.

Change-Id: Ic773c0b73062cf3b2285343bafb25d5923911834
(cherry picked from commit 5ff7bab46b3cd2cf5b585318a35030d5ed9fc459)

commit_message:
DNM: Stop using volume_api.initialize/terminate_connection

This is a test to see that a non-grenade tempest
run is only using volumes with new style attachments
since change I30a49c9e085cffc071d0ba332db67945e116bc80.

Change-Id: Iadef7baf6e74d7d1d3cf25639b8909eb1e9fff8f

commit_message:
Improve volume validation

We need to support both a source filesystem location and container
volume for the volume mounts. This change adds the ability to validate
that the provided source container is a container volume. Additionally
aligns the validation between the docker/podman methods so they operate
in the same fashion.

Change-Id: I9a55698b04dc2c5f01d776c6bdc2f26d47baf803
Closes-Bug: #1843734
(cherry picked from commit 3ce8c1ad988872234225fb3d316375c0e8ebcb36)

commit_message:
Revert "Add --cpuset-cpus support for both Docker and Podman"

The backport merged before the patch ins master, we
should not have done that because it conflicts with
I9a55698b04dc2c5f01d776c6bdc2f26d47baf803

Let's revert, put I9a55698b04dc2c5f01d776c6bdc2f26d47baf803
on top and revert the revert.

This reverts commit 1fd985d626ae08afd53a7b475946892237997e85.

Change-Id: Icd90380194e015a4efdfb54b7e7124f1d16e473c

commit_message:
Add evacuate vs rebuild contributor doc

People often get confused about the differences between
evacuate and rebuild operations, especially since the
conductor and compute methods are both called "rebuild_instance".
This change adds a contributor document which explains some
of the high and low level differences between the two operations.

Change-Id: I146fbc65237c4729ce3c28a4614589ba085dfce0
Closes-Bug: #1843439

commit_message:
CI: do not create UPLOAD_* directories when uploading images

An innocent missing slash changes rsync semantics. This changes fixes it.

Change-Id: Ib167b541b9c4db7b4ef2cc4b68a6d82f5900c07c

commit_message:
Handle new required argument for L3 Agent Extension API

The change https://review.opendev.org/620349 added a new required
argument for L3AgentExtensionAPI; this broke neutron-fwaas functional
tests in the FWLoggingTestCase class.  This adjusts the initialization
to avoid the error.

Change-Id: I97d89b1adc1eb5f859251e6cf9ca47b763554049
Resolves: #1845227

commit_message:
DIB: do not use /tmp for a virtualenv in the source build

We don't (and shouldn't) copy /tmp to the final image.

Also fix the service file permissions - it is not executable.

Change-Id: I75e09662a63768627f8123a7fe7f5d9ca2d942c5

[{'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-08-22 15:37:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2019-08-22 15:57:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't think we should do this, but some opinions on it since you're proposing this to review. IMO should just move this doc out of tc reference too if TCs don't want to be any part of it even when it comes with any difficult decision to make."}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-08-22 16:01:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This makes the TC make the decision - very much part of it'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2019-08-22 16:03:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Okay, sorry I misunderstand the pose here'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2019-08-22 16:04:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Then I do think we need something like this. IMO, I don't think the issue is to find a perfect solution, it's to find a rule and said if the concerns or conflict is happening, here's how this going to resolve and who holds the final decision. Otherwise, discussions will go on forever"}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-08-23 11:37:38.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from release-names to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-08-23 11:38:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

We should involve the whole community in the release name who deserves to be part of that as per their contribution.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-08-29 11:49:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

Currently the TC chooses the process by which releases are named. And this says the TC chooses the release name. Without more details (like how the TC chooses a release name) this is actually not changing much. I prefer a more deterministic and objective solution, so I'll be -1 on this one."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-09-17 02:20:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

messages:
[{'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-09-10 12:35:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-09-10 12:35:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

-W while we figure out the timeline of CentOS 8'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-09-10 13:16:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I agree the situation is far from ideal.

From a TripleO point of view, as soon as we have centos8 available, we'll make it our base OS as soon as we can; and therefore remove support for centos7.

The way we have dealt with Python3 testing so far, was with our fedora28 jobs, but the solution was only temporary.

I wouldn't -1/+1 this proposal but just give our point of view as of today."}, {'account_id': 13861, 'date': '2019-09-10 13:19:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I guess the deadline for getting this support matrix patch merged/get feedback would be atleast till train get's released or around release atleast, right? i hope will have some news for CentOS8 by then."}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-09-10 13:50:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@yatin - It should ideally be done by now - we need to define the openstack-ussari-python jobs soon, and have them applied when the master branch moves from train to Ussari (aka, when the stable/train branch is created).

Ideally we would have them defined already so teams could have them as non voting jobs in advance of Ussari.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-09-10 14:26:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

There are many deployments that run on-top of CentOS.  We would be doing a disservice to our community by pulling out a major system.

Also, based on the schedule, it seems all there is left to do is release work: https://wiki.centos.org/About/Building_8'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-09-10 14:29:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Some good information:

https://lists.centos.org/pipermail/centos-devel/2019-September/017680.html'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-09-10 14:29:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Or at least a lead to something..'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-09-10 16:25:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

FYI:

http://mirror.centos.org/centos-7/7/cr/x86_64/Packages/

These includes packages which will be CentOS 7.7, including Python 3.6 shipped by Red Hat.  We can use that in our testing.'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-09-10 16:26:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-09-10 16:38:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Unless we expect people to run CentOS 7.6 with CR enabled, we shouldn't run with it.

What other changes are in there (kernel, libvirt, qemu, etc)?

This is choosing the python versions - unless CentOS 8 ships with python 3.8 they should be able to use the code produced in U"}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-09-10 17:03:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Example from today in the #centos-devel room -  the CR repo had an old version of selinux-policy in it, but some of the packages in the repo were already depending on a newer version. They were broken until the new package was pushed.

The package was then pushed, so it could be tested in CI.

This is not a good idea going forward - individual project may opt in, but I do not think the TC should recommend it as a way forward.'}, {'account_id': 136, 'date': '2019-09-10 17:10:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Given the major changes to upgrade an existing cloud to CentOS 8, CentOS 7.7 could be an interesting platform to avoid major upgrades for U and would allow CentOS 8.X to be tested in parallel (but not as a certified platform until V).'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2019-09-11 10:59:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 1955, 'date': '2019-09-15 09:55:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm sure CentOS will have 7.7 in GA repos soon and they are responsive if there are issues with 7.6 + CR combination, so let's keep this as an option during the Ussuri initial development phase.
We would of course not recommend running 7.6 + CR in production to the regular users, OTOH brave teams running master should be able to handle it."}, {'account_id': 12393, 'date': '2019-09-16 18:06:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Centos 8 is releasing on 24th sept, 2019 https://twitter.com/CentOSProject/status/1173652996305170432'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-09-16 18:09:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Centos 8 is releasing on 24th sept, 2019 https://twitter.com/CentOSProject/status/1173652996305170432

Where does it actually say that? They could be talking about CentOS 7.7, which they've previously indicated is a higher priority for finishing than 8.0."}, {'account_id': 12393, 'date': '2019-09-16 18:33:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Centos 8 is releasing on 24th sept, 2019 https://twitter.com/CentOSProject/status/1173652996305170432

Sorry It says next version of CentOS, it might be CentOS 7.7.'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-09-16 21:42:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> > Centos 8 is releasing on 24th sept, 2019 https://twitter.com/CentOSProject/status/1173652996305170432
 > 
 > Where does it actually say that? They could be talking about CentOS
 > 7.7, which they've previously indicated is a higher priority for
 > finishing than 8.0.

Next major version, clarified: https://twitter.com/BitIntegrity/status/1173662817129353216"}, {'account_id': 13861, 'date': '2019-09-17 03:20:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> > > Centos 8 is releasing on 24th sept, 2019 https://twitter.com/CentOSProject/status/1173652996305170432
 > >
 > > Where does it actually say that? They could be talking about
 > CentOS
 > > 7.7, which they've previously indicated is a higher priority for
 > > finishing than 8.0.
 > 
 > Next major version, clarified: https://twitter.com/BitIntegrity/status/1173662817129353216

Also CentOS8 Wiki page[1] is updated last night 2019-09-16:- The final release will be on September 24. So i think we can get it in the supported list of Ussuri.

[1] https://wiki.centos.org/About/Building_8"}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-09-17 06:57:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I think with the fact that CentOS 7.6 with CR already contains python3, CentOS 7.7 will be out soon and the fact that CentOS 8 is planned for this month, we shouldn't really have a specific case for CentOS 8 (as its python runtime can be used already with CR).

However, I think we should make the runtimes more flexible, and let the TC propose on each cycle a "reasonable" series of runtimes, instead of relying on "what's out on some distros".

I agree that being strict on the reading of the cycle would require CentOS8 to be out as of today, else we would need to rely on 7 with py2 (but do we really?) which is very unproductive for openstack in the long run.'}, {'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2019-09-17 13:46:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

centos-8 will be about very soon and I am confident that supporting it will be easy because: we already tested fedora-28 uptream and because we have jobs running on rhel-8 on rdo.

Read https://twitter.com/CentOSProject/status/1173652996305170432'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-09-17 13:50:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

As I understand it, this change is a fallback in case CentOS 8 is not available in time to consider for the Ussuri cycle. It's probably not needed if the recently-announced news from the CentOS community holds true, but if we do wind up needing this change then it's already written. This was an alternative to having the Python runtimes for Ussuri held up as a WIP patch while waiting to find out when/whether CentOS 8 was coming."}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-09-17 22:44:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote-1

CentOS 7.7 is out, CentOS 8 is slated for release on the 24th'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-09-18 01:26:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

No matter the "decision" taken in this patch, TripleO (and probably Kolla) will test their projects on CentOS8, because this in our roadmap. This is what we have done for years and we have no plan to stop.

I honestly think there is no need to debate here in whether or not centos is a supported platform...'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2019-09-18 01:31:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote-1

For the reasons stated by Mohammed and Emilien, I am against this.'}, {'account_id': 9592, 'date': '2019-09-18 01:31:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-09-18 02:11:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think it's premature to gauge the usefulness of this change until there is actually a CentOS 8.0 release and not just a planned release date. It could also be reworked to switch to 7.7 if for some reason the announced release date slips significantly."}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-09-18 16:59:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

To keep context, CentOS 7.7 is now building/being used inside Nodepool.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-09-24 16:10:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote-1

CentOS 8 is out and Ussuri is not yet open for development, so I don't think we need this change."}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-09-24 16:14:13.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

CentOS 8 made its release date - we have no issue :)'}]

commit_message:
Remove CentOS 8 from list of OSes for Ussuri

CentOS 8 has not been release in enough time to be considered a base
OS for Ussuri.
Rather than wait another cycle with python 2.7 drop CentOS from the supported
list of OSes.

This does not force projects to stop testing 2.7, but rather does not make it
a requirement for them.

Change-Id: Iddd285c4f3421bbf76326359a4d8039d70cdde69
Signed-off-by: Graham Hayes <gr@ham.ie>

commit_message:
Make the rally job voting again

The patch https://review.opendev.org/#/c/681001/ is now merged.

Change-Id: I9d78e521c3e0221231ec6442e85d3cc66bafe366
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

(1 comment)

I tested this out, one issue I ran into was I had to restart memcached in order for the new catalog to be used. Is there a way we invalidate the cache to avoid that?'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-06-20 19:50:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 22:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > I tested this out, one issue I ran into was I had to restart
 > memcached in order for the new catalog to be used. Is there a way
 > we invalidate the cache to avoid that?

We could encourage people to use really short TTLs, but that doesn't really fix the issue. The other option jumping out at me would be to write something that watches files and reloads the cache. I tried something similar to the second approach for dynamically reloading key repositories when token keys were rotated but ran into some issues."}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-09-24 16:02:58.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-07-13 19:11:23.000000000', 'message': 'Add yaml-loaded filesystem catalog backend

The previous templated backend was not well validated, maintained,
and did not support clear v2 and v3 catalogs. This new backend
supports all the variations and edge cases (via generic data being
loaded from YAML instead of parsing an ini-style limited set of
keys).

Change-Id: I5f3a864dded0d2ed9b17eafcdbaec2073dc30b12

commit_message:
Add yaml-loaded filesystem catalog backend

The previous templated backend was not well validated and maintained.
This new backend supports all the variations and edge cases (via
generic data being loaded from YAML instead of parsing an ini-style
limited set of keys).

Co-Authored-By: wangxiyuan<wangxiyuan@huawei.com>

Closes-Bug: #1815966
Change-Id: I5f3a864dded0d2ed9b17eafcdbaec2073dc30b12

dogpile.cache has no defaults for this, so we can just change the docs to de-emphasize the old backend.  the docs are kind of pylibmc centric in any case since that was the best backend at the time."}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-11-09 17:58:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Once (if) it lands in dogpile, we'll bump the lower constraint here and migrate to pymemcache as the recommended memcache form for openstack."}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-09-24 16:02:49.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-07 20:59:16.000000000', 'message': 'Add pymemcache backend

Add pymemcache backend that replaces dogpile.cache.memcache and
oslo_cache.memcache_pool. The new pymemcache backend supports the
following bits:

* Proper configuration from the backend_argument values. All values
  are cast to appropriate types / modified as needed
* Distributed locking with context manager locking
* Proper hashing and rebalancing across multiple memcache servers
* Thread-Local and Pooled connections (native) support
    * Pooling is controlled via backend-argument "use_pooling"
    * Pool size is controlled via backend-argument "max_pool_size"
* All relevant client arguments are directly exposed via backend-arguments
* Customizable serializer/deserializer (intention is to move to msgpack
  and away from the default of pickle)

Intention will be to make the default the pymemcache backend and
deprecate the memcache/memcache_pool backends. This backend will
be submitted upstream to dogpile.cache directly for future releases.

Change-Id: I202404b7a7711ca5d6826b65567aa19120d121e0
'}]
commit_message:
Add pymemcache backend

Add pymemcache backend that replaces dogpile.cache.memcache and
oslo_cache.memcache_pool. The new pymemcache backend supports the
following bits:

* Proper configuration from the backend_argument values. All values
  are cast to appropriate types / modified as needed
* Distributed locking with context manager locking
* Proper hashing and rebalancing across multiple memcache servers
* Thread-Local and Pooled connections (native) support
    * Pooling is controlled via backend-argument "use_pooling"
    * Pool size is controlled via backend-argument "max_pool_size"
* All relevant client arguments are directly exposed via backend-arguments
* Customizable serializer/deserializer (intention is to move to msgpack
  and away from the default of pickle)

Intention will be to make the default the pymemcache backend and
deprecate the memcache/memcache_pool backends. This backend will
be submitted upstream to dogpile.cache directly for future releases.

Change-Id: I202404b7a7711ca5d6826b65567aa19120d121e0

Support KWARGS in the cache key generating function(s).

Now that oslo.cache supports kwargs, lean on the kwarg functionality.

Change-Id: I2ce3c83ec1a2470eb8a4b6091727bd30463ff33b

commit_message:
Deprecate the templated catalog

The templated catalog is not fully tested, has low usage, and has
never supported (in a clean and maintained way) v3 catalogs properly.

The catalog is slated for removal in the S release of OpenStack.

Co-Authored-By: wangxiyuan<wangxiyuan@huawei.com>

bp: deprecated-as-of-rocky
Change-Id: I7256d21310fb3509f35fcee6fc13d607a76f4708

subject: [WIP] Correct auth_token headers to be WSGI compliant

[{'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-10-26 20:05:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-10-26 20:06:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Needs sign-off by Tim Burke and fixes for the None headers.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-10-31 22:12:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Thanks for pushing this up; I hadn't bothered because I knew tests would fail on account of the None values in headers.

FWIW, my feeling is that this already may break applications that rely on current behavior (maybe they *need* that automatic hoisting from bytes to unicode on py2!) so we may as well pop off the headers, but I'd totally understand if you guys want to be more conservative. Maybe setting to empty string would be a decent middle-ground? Still False-y, but now in spec. *shrug*"}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-11-01 10:02:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Tim, I'm thinking an empty string header might be the best bet.

We'll need to look at the details on what makes the most sense and will not break folks. The other option is to pop the header off completely."}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-11-07 00:15:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
[WIP] Correct auth_token headers to be WSGI compliant

Convert the auth_token headers to always be in spec.

WIP = There are other
concerns such as where headers are set to None and passed down through
to the underlying application. Long term those should probably be
100% elminiated from the request instead of zeroed out, however those
changes may break applications relying on the current behavior.

Commit-Message authored by Morgan Fainberg <morgan.fainberg@gmail.com>,
patch supplied by Tim Burke <tim.burke@gmail.com>.

Change-Id: I787220d3149c6ed9c4614cbb0c3f99437544caa0
Closes-Bug: #1794179

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-24 15:00:48.000000000', 'message': "Be explicit about auth type in functional tests

When using the old style of '--os-url' we didn't need to be
explicit, it deduced the right type. And python-openstackclient
>= 4.0.0 it does for --os-endpoint. But when using '--os-endpoint'
with <4.0.0 we need to state 'admin_token' explicitly.

This form works in both 3.19.x and 4.0.x.

Change-Id: Ie9c76a23658b46997dcb17ba3fb7f1e700eca506
"}]
commit_message:
Be explicit about auth type in functional tests

When using the old style of '--os-url' we didn't need to be
explicit, it deduced the right type. And python-openstackclient
>= 4.0.0 it does for --os-endpoint. But when using '--os-endpoint'
with <4.0.0 we need to state 'admin_token' explicitly.

This form works in both 3.19.x and 4.0.x.

Change-Id: Ie9c76a23658b46997dcb17ba3fb7f1e700eca506

commit_message:
Fix usage of --owner filter during node list

When using --owner filter during node list, the CLI returns
this error:

  list() got an unexpected keyword argument 'owner'

Change-Id: Id751336d8d8cb99e62e465e17114e610f619c520
Story: 2006563
Task: 36660
(cherry picked from commit 89088e2aaa8329bbb98380748e5d9716734e0db6)

commit_message:
vmware-nsx: Switch to python3

Also drop BuildRequires for testing. There is no %check section. And
to enable tests, more packages are needed.

Change-Id: Ic7b02740c8822a98c6a08f3546095e462780ae09

commit_message:
Build pdf docs

This follows the instructions [1] in an attempt to build pdf docs.

To get a build, the "badge" in the README has been removed.
The other option to add some svg -> pdf support, but that seems
overkill for a badge which is effectively meaningless.

The build wanted 'xindy' to build an index, but we can turn that
off and still get useful results.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/train-pdf-support-goal

Change-Id: Icf7c22bf9d1de6fb2a74a756c370930d4c00b0b9
Story: 2006110
Task: 35397

commit_message:
Use Confluent Kafka client

The change introduces the possibility to run the API with the new
confluent-kafka client. It has to be enabled in the configuration file.

Story: 2003705
Task: 35859

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/680653
Change-Id: Id513e01c60ea584548c954a8d2e61b9510eee8de

commit_message:
add the required and optional packages for watcher

There are number of client packages that are required by watcher in
order to function correctly. See

https://opendev.org/openstack/watcher/src/branch/master/watcher/common/clients.py

So add those as requires. Also, ceilometerclient is optional so we add
it as recommends instead.

Change-Id: Icd36642ba4509ac655aaa65c059dd61d763f7b9c
(cherry picked from commit 91947caf73a964929f03a1a916dcd7644d990aa1)

commit_message:
Disable inflight validations by default

The inflight validations caused timeouts in the TripleO CI.
They should not be enabled by default. New features should not be
enabled by default in general, they should be optional.

So this patch changes the option to be --inflight-validations,
and make sure the inflights are disabled by default everywhere it's
called.

Change-Id: I082628a9480686d6a7801056c3b4bf332b4e3d95
Related-Bug: #1844446

Bandit 1.6.0 accidentally changed how the exclusion list option is

Bandit has fixed the problem.

commit_message:
Cap Bandit below 1.6.0 and update Sphinx requirement

Bandit 1.6.0 accidentally changed how the exclusion list option is
handled and breaks our use of it. Cap to the previous version until
Bandit has fixed the problem.

Sphinx 2.0 no longer works on python 2.7, so we need to start capping
it there as well.

Change-Id: Idead9b4198c6b05d72bae60dee06e5aebc223822
Reference: https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/pull/489

commit_message:
Register keystone auth options with keystoneauth1 helper functions

This replaces manual config option registration with
"keystoneauth1.loading.register_auth_conf_options" in the monasca collector.

Registering the config options manually causes the "auth_section" option to be
unavailable when using the source fetcher.

Change-Id: Iddc590ff2e321392bb0d78f603a96f5b37bda31c
Story: 2006606
Task: 36774

commit_message:
Pin python-openstackclient >= 4.0.0 in test-requirements

In change Id4f8f0224f61c1741e6a1a8369ec053bb1824e8a we added
test functionality to use os-endpoint arg instead of os-url.

This uses 4.0.0 functionality, so let's make it explicit that
we are using that.

Change-Id: I5611b797a5115c7698f208b8a7e4b84bf0dc39f3

build.

commit_message:
Update master for stable/train

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/train.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/train.

Change-Id: Iba1fb8ee8dc73110ec3bc2f8e0fe10bf03e9a5e2
Sem-Ver: feature

commit_message:
Avoid unnecessary operation of ovsdb and flows

Type of lvm.vlan is int and other_config.get('tag') is a string,
they can never be equal. We should do type conversion before
comparing to avoid unnecessary operation of ovsdb and flows.

Change-Id: Ib84da6296ddf3c95be9e9f370eb574bf92ceec15
Closes-Bug: #1843425
(cherry picked from commit 0550c0e1f66b26e7e947958fdddb60d8f309e76f)

commit_message:
Show global request ID in DevStack environment

Work in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/669079 enabled global request ID
in the debug log, but the global request ID is not shown by the default
log configuration which is used in the DevStack environment.

This patch changes the DevStack plugin to let Blazar use the same
logging configuration as other major services, enabling the global
request ID to show up in the debug log.

Change-Id: I343a7ccff82475f3aadb27d6ed741ac9b0ad2ef1

messages: [{'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-09-24 13:01:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2019-09-24 14:01:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-24 13:01:53.000000000', 'message': "Remove the requirement on either endpoint_override or os_ironic_api_version

It makes zero sense from a caller's perspective. We only use it for efficient
caching of API versions, which can safely be bypassed.

Change-Id: I00508d36ec1679cdcc9c9d1ec744d818dee74e0b
(cherry picked from commit c3e490800aaeb1f814aa0af25a9155fa6f794215)
"}]
commit_message:
Remove the requirement on either endpoint_override or os_ironic_api_version

It makes zero sense from a caller's perspective. We only use it for efficient
caching of API versions, which can safely be bypassed.

Change-Id: I00508d36ec1679cdcc9c9d1ec744d818dee74e0b
(cherry picked from commit c3e490800aaeb1f814aa0af25a9155fa6f794215)

commit_message:
Fix container configuration file path

The correct path should be hashed-container-startup-config-step_4.json
instead of hashed-docker-container-startup-config-step_4.json in
cleanup-dataplane.yml.

When this file was originally commited the path was
hashed-docker-container-startup-config-step_4.json but we have changed
it a few releases ago.

Change-Id: I901eedf64f7bd4281f94c156c33489355ff97aee

During upgrade, we stop all slave keepalived containers. However, if the
keepalived container configuration has not changed, we never restart
them.

This change fixes the issue by notifying the restart handler when the
containers are stopped.

Change-Id: Ibe094b0c14a70a0eb811182d96f045027aa02c2a

'}]
commit_message:
Ensure keepalived is restarted during upgrade

During upgrade, we stop all slave keepalived containers. However, if the
keepalived container configuration has not changed, we never restart
them.

This change fixes the issue by notifying the restart handler when the
containers are stopped.

Change-Id: Ibe094b0c14a70a0eb811182d96f045027aa02c2a
Closes-Bug: #1836368
(cherry picked from commit 6f05f1b8441a4a3097c0f596e8ea0fdf3d6240ee)

commit_message:
Only alias when policy names change

Previously, oslo.policy would generate policy files with aliased names
in the event the name was changing for backwards compatibility. This
isn't needed if the name isn't changing and only the check string is
changing.

This patch adds a conditional to the generator logic that only aliases
the old name to the new name if the name is changing. Otherwise, it
only outputs comments about the deprecation.

Co-Authored-By: Ben Nemec <bnemec@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I89ff60354e4751a5096832023441d2e6166db92a

commit_message:
Create and grant all keystone roles in service-ks-register

This ensures we execute the keystone os_* modules in one place.

Also rework some of the task names and loop item display.

Change-Id: I6764a71e8147410e7b24b0b73d0f92264f45240c

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-16 10:56:52.000000000', 'message': "Catch errors and changes in kolla_toolbox module

The kolla_toolbox Ansible module executes as-hoc ansible commands in the
kolla_toolbox container, and parses the output to make it look as if
ansible-playbook executed the command. Currently however, this module
fails to catch failures of the underlying command, and also shows tasks
as 'ok' when the underlying command was changed. This has been tested
both before and after the upgrade to ansible 2.8.

This change fixes this issue by configuring ansible to emit output in
JSON format, to make parsing simpler. We can now pick up errors and
changes, and signal them to the caller.

This change also adds an ansible playbook, tests/test-kolla-toolbox.yml,
that can be executed to test the module. It's not currently integrated
with any CI jobs.

Change-Id: I8236dd4165f760c819ca972b75cbebc62015fada
Closes-Bug: #1844114

commit_message:
Catch errors and changes in kolla_toolbox module

The kolla_toolbox Ansible module executes as-hoc ansible commands in the
kolla_toolbox container, and parses the output to make it look as if
ansible-playbook executed the command. Currently however, this module
sometimes fails to catch failures of the underlying command, and also
sometimes shows tasks as 'ok' when the underlying command was changed.
This has been tested both before and after the upgrade to ansible 2.8.

This change fixes this issue by configuring ansible to emit output in
JSON format, to make parsing simpler. We can now pick up errors and
changes, and signal them to the caller.

This change also adds an ansible playbook, tests/test-kolla-toolbox.yml,
that can be executed to test the module. It's not currently integrated
with any CI jobs.

Note that this change cannot be backported as the JSON output callback
plugin was added in Ansible 2.5.

Change-Id: I8236dd4165f760c819ca972b75cbebc62015fada
Closes-Bug: #1844114

commit_message:
CI: Reinstate use of Docker registry mirror

After modernising docker configuration
(I1215e04ec15b01c0b43bac8c0e81293f6724f278), we lost our
registry-mirrors configuration in CI that lets us use a mirror of
Dockerhub.

This change uses the new docker_custom_config variable to configure the
registry mirror.

Change-Id: I1430413c12e9d0b59e4f216ff66372de0f3a4f21

Change-Id: I80024907c575982699ce323cd9a93bab94c988d3

commit_message:
Remove some deprecated config options

Heat's [DEFAULT] deferred_auth_method is deprecated, and we are setting
the default value of 'trusts'.

Glance's [DEFAULT] registry_host is deprecated, and we do not deploy a
registry.

Change-Id: I80024907c575982699ce323cd9a93bab94c988d3
